Source: Counterfactual Story Reasoning and Generation; Paper Link: https://aclanthology.org/D19-1509.pdf
Categories: Text Generation -> Long Text Generation -> Contextual Text Generation -> Story Generation -> Story Completion
Definition: Given a premise, an initial context, an original ending, and a counterfactual context, the task is to generate a new story ending aligned with the counterfactual context and as close to the original ending as possible. Each instance consists of a five-sentence story. The premise is the first sentence of a story, and the second sentence, which is the initial context, provides more information about the story's context and the story's general plot. The original ending is the last three sentences of the story. Also, a counterfactual context is a slight modification to the initial context. You should write a new story ending that edits the original story ending as little as possible to regain coherence with the counterfactual context. To sum up, you should write the last three sentences of a story based on the premise(first sentence) and the counterfactual context(second sentence) of the story.

Positive Examples.input:
Premise: Susie was sitting on her barstool. 
 Initial Context: She kept kicking the counter with her feet. 
 Original Ending: Suddenly, her kick sent her falling backwards. The chair hit the ground with a thud and broke. Susie hurt her head and was really scared. 
 Counterfactual Context: She kept herself steady with her feet.
Positive Examples.output: Suddenly, an earthquake sent her falling backwards. The chair hit the ground with a thud and broke. Susie hurt her head and was really scared.
Positive Examples.explanation: The generated new ending is perfect. It considers the counterfactual context and changes required parts in original ending.

Positive Examples.input:
Premise: Celeste rode her motorcycle across the woods. 
 Initial Context: When she almost arrived at the intersection, a moose appeared. 
 Original Ending: She didn't have enough time to brake and drove towards the moose. They were both knocked out. She eventually got up and called the police. 
 Counterfactual Context: When she almost arrived at the intersection, a deer appeared.
Positive Examples.output: She didn't have enough time to brake and drove towards the deer, They were both knocked out. She eventually got up and called the police.
Positive Examples.explanation: The new ending is correct. Because new context doesn't change the original ending.

Positive Examples.input:

 Initial Context: Upon awaking he yawned. 
 Original Ending: He looked in the mirror. He saw something in his eye. He washed his face to clean his eyes. 
 Counterfactual Context: He woke up and stayed in bed because he felt sick.
Positive Examples.output: Then he looked in the mirror. He saw something in his eye. He washed his face to clean his eyes.
Positive Examples.explanation: New ending is correct as it considers the new counterfactual context and only adds required new sentences in the ending to follow the counterfactual context.

Positive Examples.input:
Premise: Ana had just had a baby girl. 
 Initial Context: She wanted her girl to have pierced ears. 
 Original Ending: She took her baby to the studio and had her ears pierced. Then she fastened tiny diamond studs into the piercings. Ana loved the earrings. 
 Counterfactual Context: She didn't like the idea of having her ears pierced.
Positive Examples.output: She decided not to take her baby to the studio to get her ears pierced. So she took tiny diamond stickers and stuck them to her ear. Ana loved the fake earrings.
Positive Examples.explanation: The new counterfactual context required heavy changes in original ending. And the new ending is also based on the premise. Hence, the generated new ending is correct.

Negative Examples.output: She counted down the days until the Saturday of her party. When she woke up Saturday morning, she felt sick. She had to cancel the party.
Negative Examples.explanation: This is the wrong ending. As it doesn't have the required changes to follow the counterfactual context.

Premise: Rocky was cooking at his job. 
 Initial Context: While cooking he left outside to smoke. 
 Original Ending: When he came back all the food was burnt. Rocky's manager seen what rocky had done. He fired rocky on the spot. 
 Counterfactual Context: While cooking he stayed by the food and smoked.
output: He got distracted and suddenly the food was burnt. Rocky's manager seen what rocky had done. He fired rocky on the spot.

Instances.input:
Premise: Two gymnasts, Ed and Steve, were having a handstand contest. 
 Initial Context: Neither of them showed any strain after a few minutes. 
 Original Ending: Ed began to taunt Steve to psych him out. Steve has low self-esteem so it began to work. Steve fell over shortly after and felt sad. 
 Counterfactual Context: Ed started to lose his balance and fell over.
output: Ed didn't want Steve to fall over too by taunting him to psych him out. Steve has low self-esteem so it began to work. Steve fell over shortly after and felt sad even though he won.

Instances.input:
Premise: Bill was riding his bike down the street. 
 Initial Context: He rolled to a stop sign, but didn't stop. 
 Original Ending: A car was passing through the intersection. Bill's bike hit the tail end of the car. Bill had to be hospitalized for a week. 
 Counterfactual Context: His car had recently broke down and he had no choice but to ride his bike to work.
output: A car had been passing through the intersection and clipped him. Bill's bike had hit the tail end of the car. Bill had to be hospitalized for a week after that.

Instances.input:
Premise: Kim went to the grocery store to prepare for a hurricane. 
 Initial Context: The grocery store was packed with people doing the same. 
 Original Ending: Kim was only able to find 3 gallons of the 10 gallons of water needed. She waited close to an hour in line before she could check out. When she left the wind was high, the hurricane was on the way. 
 Counterfactual Context: No one else was out.
output: Kim was only able to find 3 gallons of the 10 gallons of water needed because the rest had all been bought by earlier shoppers. She checked out quickly. When she left the wind was high, the hurricane was on the way.

Instances.input:
Premise: Evan was nine but sometimes still wet the bed. 
 Initial Context: He was invited to a sleepover but afraid to attend. 
 Original Ending: He did not want anyone to discover his secret! Then his mom bought him a pack of absorbent underwear to wear. Evan felt much more secure with the backup underwear on! 
 Counterfactual Context: He never had sleepovers.
output: He did not want anyone to discover his secret! Then his mom bought him a pack of absorbent underwear to wear. Evan felt much more secure with the backup underwear on!
